posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

>>9606491
You're a fucking retard. It's called "practice". "Practice" is getting better at a game's mechanics until you master it and are ready to react to and tackle anything the game throws at you. Practicing at something like Tetris or Street Fighter will cause you to get better over time, just like ANY sport. Practice is sparring with your coach to become a better boxer. Practice is going to the batting cages and getting good at hitting any kind of throw.

"Grinding" is when you do the same damn thing over and over but see no increase in your overall skill, but the game makes you do it in order to continue anyway. When you go do the same fucking menial task over and over to make an arbitrary number go up in order to progress. That has ZERO impact on how good you are and is solely there to pad out game length. There is no difference in actual real life skill level between a level 10 FF player and a level 90 FF player beyond their ability to not die in one hit. Grinding is a high schooler dribbling 200,000 times and then suddenly they're a star athlete in basketball.
>b-but what about lifting weights or running laps?? it's the same thing!
If you seriously can't see the difference between getting physically stronger irl, and your virtual character getting stronger while you're still the same, you are seriously fucked in the head buddy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9603956
>It's more than just edgy dark Coldsteel the Hedgehog dark, there's a sense of rust and sinister feelings and it's all weird and I like it a lot.
I think that it does grimdark edge the right ways, it's ever present and never lets up. Every character has a strong motivation (usually vengeance for horrible wrongdoings), and just the same they are mostly very twisted and dark persons who at times are outright villainous.
They all partake in this reckless and massively destructive tournament to kill each other for the whims of someone who could just as well be the devil, and many of them will be doublecrossed if they win, said devil delighting in putting his boot on the face of people who have (relatively) noble intentions, while preferring to accommodate those who only want revenge.

Everything about the setting in Twisted Metal Black is bitter, horrible, bleak, sad, cruel, hopeless, and unfair, and it's suitable too, being that the game takes place inside of the mind of Needles Kane, aka Sweettooth. It's based on how a cynical, sadistic, and black hearted serial killer interprets the world, he sees little good in others, and he's firm in how being good never pays, how life will inevitably shit on you, or how do-gooders are secretly twisted and vile like him, he scoffs at the perceived double standards and fancies himself the only one who truly sees the world for what it is.
Might makes right to him, and since he's capable of cruel murder and can get away with it, he feels he deserves to, anyone who's a victim of anything deserves it for being weak. This all also fits with how at times, the edge is so thick and dark that it becomes comical, for Needles is a clown.

TMNT actually has a lot in common with Getsu Fuma Den, a 1987 Famicom game by Konami which seems to have had a cult following there. You put all the arcade roms into
>C:\...\Mame\Roms\
Don't unzip the roms or change any filenames.

>C:\...\Mame\Roms\a2600\

The base romset for the arcade games is only like 72 GB. Only download the CHDs as needed as they close to a TB and only needed for few games.

>>9610393
>You need all the ROMS for a game to be able to play it? That's insane.

He's trying to bring up the fact that many arcade games, especially older ones, were split across several or dozens of chips. These are all dumped separately. However, MAME has supported just putting these files into an archive for decades now if not since launch. Technically some console games do this too, NES games had at least two ROM chips for graphics and program data, they are just dumped into a single file. Nobody has exclusively distributed MAME ROMS or sets with the ROMS separate for ages now. Nowadays there are even merged sets which put different revisions of a game in a single archive.

>>9610407
>You don't need all the roms but it's not well documentated which ones you need for every given game.

It's extremely well documented, the names are all standard. Plenty of MAME database sites that tell you the name of the archive, which will contain all the individual roms within it, nobody downloads them separately.

>>9610407
There are three versions of the current MAME set. Split, Merged, and Un-Merged.
Split is every unique group of roms in it's own .zip file, meaning all games using the QSound HLE will just be looking for a qsound_hle.zip in your /roms directory. You'll need the Parent ROM, and whatever Clone ROM you want for that specific region/revision of the game. Merged is the BIOS files, parent, and all clones in the same .zip file, meaning all needed files to make the Parent work are present, and with some work you can get the Clones to work as well. Which is good if you aren't picky about the region/revision. Un-Merged is the parent and clones having their own .zip files that contain ALL needed files to work. There's a great deal of duplication because of this, but every single .zip file is stand-alone and you can be certain that one .zip will have everything you need.
Split is for people who want to be efficient and have everything, Merged is for people who want to have everything but have a cleaner directory with less .zip's. Un-Merged is for people who just want to play individual games and don't wanna be bothered with hunting down all the required BIOS or device files, and don't care if they lose a GB or two to duplicate files.
Why exactly are you downloading the Split set, freaking out over nothing working right, and downloading the ENTIRE fucking set to fix it? Why not just download the Un-Merged set?

I have made a musical discovery regarding an old favorite: The "drugstore" (weapons, items etc) music from Earthbound is modeled on "Maxwell's Silver Hammer", by The Beatles. Although they are musically distinct, they have a clear similarity:

-Both melodies are these happy, mid-tempo, plodding but slightly subversive things.
-The pitch goes jauntily up-and-down in both cases.
-the ending of each "verse" is unmistakably the same. Try singing "sure that she was dead" to the ending of the drugstore music before it repeats again (the drugstore take adds two beats after this)
-the developers were clearly into the Beatles, per an early in-game Onett joke.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mJag19WoAe0
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OOXFR5SQnYk

>And what is your Crash opinion?
I agree with you in general. Crash 2 is the easiest to casually play and my favourite overall. It has the best secrets in the coloured gems; there are hints but the game never spells it out for you unlike the remake. There are just some oddities that get the noggin joggin and encourage you to try new things. Wonder why Turtle Woods has a single bounce crate on that crate wall? Why is it the only level where the box counter stays after I get the gem and say /0? Wonder if I could get through the level without breaking any boxes...

Crash 1 has the tightest level themeing; you're going on an adventure across the islands, gradually moving from nature to polluting industry and the levels reflect that. I fucking love that the silhouette of Cortex's castle can be seen from Sunset Vista.

Crash 3 is the most wacky and cartoony and high energy. It's fun, and the bosses are the best, but it loses the strong themeing that was in Crash 1 and to a lesser degree Crash 2. The powers are cool but break the game

I will say it has a lot of "pizazz". It's one of those games where shooting enemies feels very satisfying. Everything has a good crunchy impact about it. Depends what you're looking for in a game, really. It's probably not the most high tier competitive shooter. It doesn't have the smoothest controls. They work, but they're of their time.

Do I like it a lot? Yes. Are a new generation about to be introduced to it, only to piss and moan because it's not Overwatch? Also yes.

>>9611264
Today I am officially starting /vr/'s first Serious Sam mapping project called "A Serious Case Of /vr/"
If you're new to mapping with SED1 then check out this quick start guide: https://rentry.org/vy4qr

A Serious Case of /vr/ Rules:
>Map must be made for Serious Sam The Second Encounter 1.07 version (this is the most up to date retail version on Steam/GOG)
>Usage of custom textures, sounds, and music is approved and encouraged
>Usage of custom entities or other mods is NOT allowed. Outside of textures, sounds, and music your map should be 100% vanilla with 1.07
>Please provide a readme listing your name (even if it's anonymous), map name, and sources for any custom content used
>Map must be beatable and have proper co-op support
>Do not make edits of existing maps
>Project host has the final say and can deny your entry if it is not up to /vr/ "standards" (please put some effort into your map)
>Rules are subject to change
>Deadline: TBD

Tips:
>Trigger a checkpoint whenever a new weapon is picked up to ensure everyone spawns with an up-to-date arsenal
>Make co-op portals for arenas that get closed off (and/or one-way doors so players don't get trapped)
>Aim to balance your map around Serious difficulty first, but don't be afraid to make support for other difficulties later
>Try to keep co-op in mind when balancing fights, drawn out reinforcement spawners are not fun to wait on
>Hot starts are not that common in Serious Sam, make a "lobby" for players to jump around in without risk of triggering anything (useful for co-op)
>A good fight is more enjoyable than a good looking room, don't stress yourself out over brushwork
>Use the official maps as references (I won't berate you for coping models, texture work, etc. from official maps) (You can have multiple maps open at the same time and switch between them on the fly in the editor)
>Don't forget to make a thumbnail for your level
>Ask questions if you need help
>Get creative with secrets!

Because the dev made basically made every wrong decision and the resulting game is simply not fun to play:

3. Giant, boring levels that you constantly have to go through
4. Couldn't keep it in his pants. Usually people are willing to overlook one weird fetish, but not two at once. If it was just bara men, or just furries, it would've been fine, but bara furries is over the line. The point of fanservice is to attract potential players, not to alienate them.

This game is extremely educational, it should be studied by any fledgling game designer, you can write long essays on what went wrong with it.

If you are too good at taking and defending your turf, the game punishes you by taking away any challengers. You have to leave at least one territory for each opposing gang if you want to be able to defend or invade turf again later. Can be somewhat fixed by glitching the game to create turf all over the map, but it's a half-assed solution.
Also, despite taking over the entire city, you really don't gain any benefit for doing it besides knowing there won't be other gangs waiting there to shoot at you. Pretty much everything else in the game will reward you for being good at it, even dancing can come in useful for the dates. Your reward for getting all the turf is no more gang wars to enjoy.

- Las Venturas felt pretty empty besides the casinos

>>9608448
Okay, let's start at the end(?), GTA III is the only game that "really" happened 1:1, in real-time.
Vice City Stories is Lance's recollection of his brother and his adventures when the two first arrived in Vice City, maybe it's survivor's guilt, but Lance puts Vic on a pedestal, hence why Vic practically babysits Lance the whole game.
Vice City is a movie by Tommy Vercetti showing his rise to power, more or less, decide for yourself what mission threads are in the movie and what had to be taken out for time.
San Andreas, okay you're gonna have to just keep up with me on this because this is REALLY autistic, Carl is a small-time criminal from LS, goes to LC, and comes back to LS, everything up until the Desert actually happens, Carl DID buy the air field, but the only mission that really happens is N.O.E where you have to drop supplies off on the other side of the map, everything else is a dehydration hallucination because Carl's too stupid to hydrate while watching flight videos and spy movies, The Truth missions are Carl and the Truth tripping out on Peyote in the desert, talking while Truth tells Carl about all the stuff he knows, the game picks back up with reality when Woozie calls Carl and tells him about Las Venturas, the two become partners Carl saves Madd Dogg and that's how CJ became a success, Toreno was grateful for CJ not only taking down the Loco Syndicate and delivering those supplies, and Sweet is miraculously let go.
LCS is another game that happened in real-time but it's not 1:1, some parts are more embellished, and could be chalked up to dreams and Tony leaving the TV on after a hard day.
Manhunt is a MSNBC documentary/news story, spliced in with snuff films because some high schooler wanted to be edgy, taped over, as we all know a Children's Show about a robochef.
Bully is Jimmy's story about Bullworth, some things like busting people out of asylums never happened, but to spark interest to the audience is sprinkled throughout the story.

>>9604206
>Not in RA

Hope to set up hotkey recording in RetroArch:

1) Create a txt-file, paste in the following lines, save as "normal.cfg"
vcodec = libx264
acodec = libmp3lame
pix_fmt = yuv420p
scale_factor = 2
threads = 3
video_crf = 18
video_preset = superfast
video_tune = animation
audio_bit_rate = 320000
sample_rate = 44100
format = matroska

2) Boot RetroArch

3) Settings > Recording > Set 'Recording Quality' to 'Custom'

4) Settings > Recording > As 'Custom Record Configuration' select 'Custom.cfg' from step 1)

5) Optional: Settings > Recording > Set 'Use GPU Recording' to 'On' if you want to record video after shaders and scaling have been applied - which is not a good idea if the purpose of the recording is to post WebMs on 4chan. File size is too small > image quality too low. (Warning: This is resource intensive and I recommend you leave it turned off.)

6) Settings > Input > Hotkey Binds > Set 'Recording Toggle' to any key / button you like or start and stop the recording process from the Quick Menu. (You also set a custom directory for saving the recordings, standard will be *\recordings in your RetroArch installation

If your PC is really beefy you can also try the following preset instead of normal.cfg and call that lossless.cfg. A word of warning though, the resulting files will be huge
ormat = matroska
threads = 3
vcodec = libx264rgb
video_tune = animation
pix_fmt = bgr24
video_qp = 0
acodec = flac

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9590467
Tiger-Heli is probably the best beginner shmup there is as it forces you to learn all of the basics to complete it without dying, and also has very forgiving checkpoints. Ideally, you want to practice sections without dying though, as you can just brute-force through sections with dying.

It's just a very basic game that beginners would probably find too primitive/boring, and the main flaw is just that the terrain and enemies are so limited that it's hard to actually know/memorize which section you're at because it all flows together.

Deep down they're all pretty much the same and everyone always recommends the same old ones so here's my list with a few twists and games that don't immediately come to mind when we think of shmups:
Parodius: Non-Sense Fantasy (SNES)
Psyvariar 2: The Will to Fabricate (Xbox)
DoDonPachi DaiOuJou (PS2/Xbox)
Space Invaders (GBC)
Radiant Silvergun (Saturn)
ESP Ra. De. (PS2)
Soukyugurentai (Saturn)
Twinkle Star Sprites (Neo Geo)
Cho Aniki Bakuretsu Ranto-hen (SNES)
Warning Forever (Windows)
Bangai-O (Dreamcast)
Panzer Dragoon Saga (Saturn)
Panzer Dragoon Orta (Xbox)
Pocky & Rocky (SNES)
Iridion II (GBA)
Sin & Punishment (N64)
Lords of Thunder (TurboGrafx)
Sengoku Ace (Arcade/PS2)
Rez (PS2)
Touhou Koumakyou: the Embodiment of Scarlet Devil (Windows)
Sonic Wings 3 (Neo Geo)

Just remember if the cover art has a cute anime girl then it's worth playing.

>>9590227
All depend on what you are looking for.

Any shmup can be your first it really, depend on the dedication you want to poor on it, even more true when nowdays you have training tools, adjustable auto fire,rewind and save states which make the training way more efficient and short.

Also be aware that some games can be average to hard to 1CC but very hard to insane 2ALL ( 2nd Loop), some Psikyo games are like this for example.

Now for the recommendation I try to give you some easily emulated or game available on steam or ACA :
Relatively easy.
Dariusburst AC : depend on the route but it mostly easy/mild hard at best for an 1CC)
Akai Katana got released last month it's a mild difficulty cave with a lot of thing to learn from.
Area 88 is fun arcade game you may learn movement and placement, learning curve is kind of flat but expect a small pick at level 5. give the snes/sfc version a try too.

Normal
R-type leo is kind of the same you may also learn some stuff about force and option (harder at level 4).
Fighting Hawk is close to Area 88 but as a verti. not too hard not too easy
Metal Black is between the 2 but you won't learn that much from as the game is weird AF.
some others weird shmup ; fun but wont learn much from them.
Xexex mild 1CC on the japanese version. (2all is another story)
X-Multiply is slightly harder to 1CC but at least you won't have a burnout dealing with it 2ALL even if it's hard.

Mild hard
Game Tengoku is cute nice and fun and you will learn tons of shit and tricks, but 2ALL is on another story, way too hard for it own good.
Dragon Spirit is old but it one of my favorite games ever, it come from a time where you needed a separate button to shoot sol enemies. Maybe a little bit long and learning curve can be a bitch.
Outzone depend on the version and weapon management can be a nice game to pick.

Also most Psikyo and Cave games 1CC can be put here.

posts.com: OP, literally NO secondary mission in STALKER is worth doing. Unless you specifically have the item they are asking for on-hand and need the extra money that badly, there is no reason to accept one. You can make far more money with far less effort just getting into a fight and harvesting goods off of the dead. Ammo, medical supplies, grenades, all light-weight and sell for good money. If you aren't playing Anomoly or similar, the guns can get you decent cash as well, though they will eat up a lot more of your weight limit.

>>9607112
I just got finished playing AoD. I think this game was excellent when it came to the music (that main menu theme!) and the overall plot and presentation was great. Lara never looked better imo. The gameplay is what kills it. The last levels from Strahov onward are simply unfinished and cut extremely short. I would have loved to see more of that world and the stuff they would have us raid from tombs. Each classic tomb raider game really did something completely different from the last one. Collecting an Atlantean artifact from lost civilisations that developed from a cataclysm, destroying an Italian cult focussed around a Chinese dagger that turns you into a dragon hunting through sunken ships (interesting choice of tomb), Collecting meteorite splinters from all over the world for a weird social darwinist gone power-mad only to then kill him, and then a game focussed around the apocalypse being started by a haughty Lara picking up the amulet of Seth (1999 had many apocalypse plots, even V:tM Redemption), Chronicles was all over the place, and finally this weird cinematic plot of a serial killer and Icons that you need to collect and periapt shards you need to defeat the weird half-angel Nephilim race.

Tomb Raider was a wild ride. It really pisses me off that the gameplay for the final game was so piss-poor. There is lots of potential in that game and afaik they wanted to do so much more. TR Legend is just a big dumb action game with quicktime events that is over before you know it and doesn't really do anything with the king Arthur plot, not for all the dumb talking they do over it.

Even at around level 20-ish, with magic-boosting equips it can do over 7000 damage, which is enough to make most of the remainder of the game a joke. And there's zero drawbacks to spamming it. It's actually pretty insane.

>>9600617
>is that a bad boxart? cause it makes me wanna research it and see what its about

average solid platform game from the looks of it. 2d platformer in a 3d environment, like Pandemonium, or the sidescroller levels in Crash Bandicoot. The catch is that since you are a spider, you can walk up on walls and ceilings, which makes some of the paths very trippy. Also you can get weapons like bombs, boomerangs, guns, poison cannons, which turn you into a half-robotic spider with a cannon arm and such. Your default weapon is just a melee attack, so having ranged attacks will help.


Boxart is actually very accurate in that regard.

>>9610640
Both of them have Ocarina of Time which is the exact same as the N64 1.1 version for non-speedrunning purposes. The only real, true change is that all the button icons are changed to look like the gamecube ones, so B is red and Z is shown as L.
Bottom one also comes with Master Quest, which was a new version of Ocarina of Time that has remixed dungeon layouts that are different with more enemies in them. You can actually download a version of the rom that can be run on real N64 with no differences if you prefer.
The thing with Majora's Mask is that it's super buggy and prone to crashing all the time, don't know what it is but because of how saving works in Majora it can lead to you losing an hour or more of progress because the game decides to crap itself. Stick with the N64 or virtual console versions instead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9610640
They WERE a decent way to play OoT back in the day if you didn't have an N64 or the original game. It runs at double the resolution with 480p support, so at a glance it looks crisper. However, there are some effects they don't properly emulate, so in that sense it's inferior. The controller setup, while serviceable, is not quite as optimized for the game, especially when taking differences in stick sensitivity into account (at least for me, aiming was always harder in the GC version). These days, if you absolutely have to play on real hardware, I'd go with the N64 version, but only if you have a CRT to go with it since N64 games look like ass otherwise. Otherwise, I'd just emulate, since that's what you'd be doing with the GC version anyway.

As for MM, stay away. It has random crashes, and MM is the worst possible game to have such a problem.

Then I went through the Japanese Bloodlines, killed Dracula with a loaded spear. I tried again and without a special attack, I easily killed him. I run after the countess more.
Rondo is the easiest, in fact, I was just a noob. You jump over fireballs and pass under the monster. The 5 bosses and the shaft mantle are much more difficult.
It's easy in Dracula X, except for the level in front of him, you just sit carefully in the first phase, and in the second you throw dozens of axes at him. Death is harder. I can't honestly go through the last 2 levels without saving, but I don't cheat on the boss, I beat the whole hp.
In Super 4, it took me a long time to get used to the pillars of fire, lightning. I figured out how to beat meat, but in the next attempt I did not take damage and killed.
In Chronicles ps1 is not difficult in a contractual fashion.
In Rebirth, I trained perfectly to go through the first two phases, I did not understand why the damage did not pass in third,
NES parts are also problematic if you do not use Sypha in the third.

As a result, I trained Dracula the most in 1, 3, 4 and Rebirth

>>9599512
After becoming an adult and getting into classical music, the series' growing pretensions from 6 onward make me think they were actually trying to create interactive operas.

Operas often only change scenes at the beginning of a new act. So to tell a complete narrative in 3-5 scenes, exposition dumps are a big part of it. It can sometimes be like an episode of Springer with a dynamic soundtrack that reacts to two characters having an argument over something that happened offscreen and the details slowly emerge as they yell stuff at each other accusingly, for example. If you imagine the flashback scenes as the group talking to one another, and Uematsu's music being written to pull you into caring about the sudden left turn of the narrative, it makes sense.

I'm not saying its brilliant or that there wouldn't be a better way to do it, but as the series got more serious, its pretty obvious that they considered opera an artistic aspiration for the series and now that I'm familiar enough with the tropes of Wagner and Italian Verismo operatic storytelling, the way 6 onwards delivers story beats feels similar to the way Puccini (Aeris' death) or Wagner (giant, world ending sword duel climax) would present them.

>>9599610
Good post. Most FF fans are completely artistically illiterate and can't see any nuance. Sephiroth is shown to be cold and ruthless even when he was a "hero." He was raised to be a killing machine, held up as a figurehead for Shinra's propaganda, showered with praise for slaughtering any perceived enemy, and we learn from Lucretia that he was never even held by his mother as a baby; he was whisked off by scientists to be a research specimen the moment he was born. You don't need to be a psychologist to see how fucked up someone would be from living a life like that. Even before the Nibelheim incident, he was, at best, a functional sociopath with a massive superiority complex, but most players completely miss all of that and take the claim that he's a hero at face value.

I'd also argue that he doesn't actually give a shit about Jenova or the Ancients. Those are just post-hoc rationalizations he uses to justify his desires. When he reads in Gast's research notes that Jenova is an Ancient, he claims that entitles him to take the planet back from the humans who betrayed the Ancients. Later, when he travels through the Lifestream and learns the truth about Jenova (that she was actually just a monster that wiped out the Ancients), he twists it around and says that he's entitled to rule the planet because Jenova was even greater than the Ancients were. In other words, all he really wants is to satisfy his own ego by elevating himself up to godhood compared to the rest of the world, and he'll use whatever excuse he can come up with to justify it.

>>9600431
Its cool being able to understand the references when you notice them. Curtains Down from Blood Money is a lot more satisfying when you understand the context of the scene the target is playing out, for instance.

The opera is called Tosca, and thats the ending scene. There's at least a dozen Kojima-tier absurd plot twists that precede it, but basically the character being executed believes that its a mock execution, because the chief of police pardoned him but had to keep up appearances because he's known for being tough on crime. Usually on stage, that character acts like a chad with no fear of death, and his girlfriend is singing these joking lyrics about what a good actor he is while the music itself is really tense and clues you in that he's actually fucked and the police chief didn't actually give the order to pardon. He gets shot and dies with a look of shock on his face, and his girlfriend jumps off a cliff to avoid arrest, then curtains the end.

So in a meta sense, the two targets are actually playing the roles of the two opera characters, and 47 is actually playing the role of the executioner. Tosca is pretty babbys first opera tier so its not hard to see why it'd be one they'd be looking for level material in, but the way they pulled it off is actually really impressive.

>>9609010
When the Amiga first came out in 85, it was a graphical powerhouse compared to the EGA graphics IBM just brought out the year before. But when the VGA came out in 89, it blew the Amiga's OCS right out of the water. Amiga responded with ECS in 1990, which was still inferior. Then they tried again in 92 with AGA, which was an improvement but still lacking compared to the faster 4MB VGA cards of the era. They were working on something that might have been able to compete with the Voodoo in terms of graphics, maybe, but they went bankrupt before they could finish.
Doesn't help that even the best Amiga had a stock 40Mhz 68xxx CPU in 1994, but Pentiums were hitting 100Mhz.

>>9606213
i can help you anon, Im just gonna assume the ps2 version plays like the arcade version, so heres my help.
( you will have to race in mt tho)
with the delta on arcade mode
>desert
first thing you should know, don't break or downshift in this stage
at the start, foot on pedal, after go, wait until the revs drop to 7, then shift 2, then keep the revs at 7 and shift 3, then when you see the revs going to the red part of the gauge, shift 4 (and you do this in every stage)

next is a zig zag, left-right, don't take the inside on the left turn if you are not very good at sega rally yet, because ur gonna loose control, even I don't like to take the inside, its really hit or miss, so just avoid the inside, left, right, carefull with the cars, right turn carefull with the inside, makes ur car jump,

now we approach an important right turn, you have to steer right and let the car steer itself, if you feel like the car is gonna crash correct its trajectory with small movements and remember, try not to drift, drifting makes you loose speed, so make a straight line if possible and take off like a rocket

then comes the jumps, just jump, but, on the 2 and 3 jump you should steer left so you enter the zigzag (or easy left) with ur car in a 10 degree angle to the left

then comes another zig zag, just make a straight line

then comes that big right turn with the helicopter at the end, you should be riding on the grass (outter) part of the turn then steer right and try to touch the inside of the turn and then try to get out of the turn as close as possible to the inside, ur gonna jump, and you want to jump at a speed of at least 210kmh

finish

i gonna do seperate posts to bump the thread, also sumimasen for esl

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9606313
>forest
start, carefull with the car,do a straight line until the right turn, to enter the right turn place urself on the left grass side then steer right and take the turn on the inside (basically just ride on the right grass part of the track) straight line and then you want to get out of the turn on the left side of the track, stay there, carefull with the cars, right turn, take it on the inside and you want to get out of the turn on the left side of the turn (you want to be as close as possible to the stone wall on ur left), stay on the grass part then when you approach the tunel go smoothly to right while steering left, this while reduce drifting

tunel, left turn, place urself on the right side of the tunel and turn left, take the inside, ur gonna drift but go easy with the drifting, then take off on the right side, simple as
pass the tunel, do a straight line, left turn, place urself outside (right), when ur on the dirt part of the track downshift to 3 and steer left, you want to do a "late apex" on this one and come out in the right side of the track, if you do it correctly ur gonna take off like a fucking rocket and you will be able to shift (revs apraoching the red line) back to 4 and win some speed

now right turn, take it on the outside (left), downshift to 3, steer right and just let the car slide (of course try to correct the trajectory)
now what i like to do here is trying to get to the right side and in the midle of the long turn shift back to 4 and make a straight line and get out of the dirt part like a f1 car

do a straight line, jump, carefull with the cars

now a right hairpin turn, this is tricky

this depends on the other cars, if they are making the hairpin turn try to take the turn on the outside to prevent collision, how to do

after passing the checkpoint, downshift to 2 and steer right then drift all the way unitll the exit, then apraoching the dirt part, shift to 3, dont shift to 4, aproach the left turn in 3

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9610126
It's mostly likely that a leaked clock capacitor is what caused this. It is a well known issue with the OG Xbox from hardware versions 1.0 through 1.5 - so almost all of them. Only 1.6 are exempt from this problem I believe. Since you meantioned the system clock not working it's pretty much guaranteed that it leaked and ceased to function. The end result of this failure is the acid corroding the circuits underneath or near where the cap is placed on the board, eventually killing the power button. To repair this is beyond my knowledge or capabilities. I can't even tell you whether it's a feasible option or not. This is why every single Xbox out there that's below hardware v1.6 needs to be openend and have it's clock cap removed or better yet, replaced - the system can run without it, as you have seen since yours is dead. RIP your Xbox

The process to fix it will be:
>remove the capacitor
>clean the board
>repair damaged power button traces

Most of the small components near the capacitor are only essential for the clock circuit, so they won't need to be replaced if they've been melted off the board.

posts.com:
Unleash your autism and design your own console architecture. Here's mine.
>68000 CPU clocked at 8MHz
>128KB main RAM
>16KB bitmap VRAM
>graphic mode 0: a tile bitplane controller similar to that of the TMS9918 (used by MSX, pc engine, and sega master system alike) and VIC-II chip, up to 320x240 PAL resolution, 32 colors out of 512, uses 32K of the main RAM and eats up a few cycles during memory access
>graphic mode 1: bitmap raster chip similar to the Atari GTIA chip but with twice as much graphics memory (16K VRAM), 240x180 PAL resolution, pixel doubling and graphic mirroring features, DMA, and no hardware collision detection, useful for 3D graphics or anything that works better in bitmap
>bus controller to alternate between mode 0 and mode 1
>sound: 6-8 channel PSG with selectable waveforms for each of the channels
>storage: 64 pin cartridge, hardware ROM decompression system, floppy drive expansion with 512KB additional RAM, uses continuous spiral floppy disk format just like the one found in Mitsumi QuickDisks
>interconnectivity: data port to be connected to audio tape or CD players
>price: more expensive than PC-Engine but more affordable than the Mega Drive, floppy expansion would be around the same price as the console or slightly less
>release date: shouldn't be further than 1986 or 1987, the custom chips are based on existing hardware solutions and shouldn't require too much R&D, the rest could be built from off-the-shelf parts

posts.name: OP
posts.com:
>>9603717
Features:
>high speed 2D graphics with 32 colours on screen simultaneously, pretty shabby colours compared to the PC engine, but it could run street fighter and mortal combat games without any issue except for reduced colours
>2D tile graphics could be altered on the go without a blitter just like the VIC-II, allowing for some impressive tricks
>high speed bitmap graphics with relatively low latency between the CPU and the display screen, helps running 2.5D or 3D games faster than the Atari ST and Amiga do, but sprite/tile graphics can't be used in this mode because the CPU needs to hog all the memory bus all the time
>game publishers can choose between cartridge, floppy, audio tape, or even CD, giving them more freedom and lower price for the consumers
>hardware decompression routine, allowing denser ROM capacity and cheaper carts
>continuous spiral disk reading, floppy software is completely loaded into the RAM in one go
>audio jack, could be used to store and load save states and software into and from an audio tape, 16 bit CPU should be able to transfer data on a tape faster than an 8 bit one
>overall, an affordable 68000 console released before the mega drive and snes, inferior 2D graphics due to the smaller colour memory and simpler 2D architecture, but roughly equal framerate, higher resolution, and faster 3D graphics

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The most interesting hardware chooses one area to be good at and goes hard in that area.

Dual Z80 at 6mhz, they were about $5 each in the 80's. Each cpu has 8k ram each. Graphics chip is also memory mapped to 2nd cpu with 8 kb. Both cpus have 4kb that only can accessed 1 at a time to copy data to each other. One cpu is for the game data and the other cpu is to control the graphics. Graphics chip does 320x240 but since there is not enough memory it would be heavily tiled. Zx speccy style colour attributes except that colour pallete can be manipulated by timing of the pulses sent to the chip as well as the normal bit data. Customizable colour attribute tiles can be moved around for more detailed areas. Can change timing of attribute tiles from the pulses from cpu at will to change the width and length of colour tiles. The hue would be controlled by timing from the cpu so maybe you could get many thousands of colours. Eg black would be 1 cpu tick and white would be 100 ticks so anything in between would be gray. Combine that with the 16 main colours for many different shades and thousand of colours. Colour pallate can be manipulated by cpu in the analog domain. Simple bit shifting to allow for smooth scrolling and using softsprites from 2nd cpu.
Cartridge connected using upper 32kb of first z80, your choice to use whole 32k or use half the bits for bank switching. Dual pokey for sound because it sounds cool.
Result, 8 bit system with many thousands of colours and not that many more transistors than zx speccy.

>>9603717
I drop development of the Atari 7800, ST, XEGS, and all other hardware projects at Atari.
Everything is put into the development of a new unified Atari console: the Atari CD.

The Atari CD is a 16-bit console with a rough power level equivalent to the PC Engine CD.
But there is no cartridge base system.
It is CD-based from the beginning.
The familiar Atari controller is redesigned to use a d-pad plus six buttons + start/select. Games are becoming more complex and commonly arcades use three buttons so double it just to be sure and future proof.
The CD drive is used primarily for
1. music
2. extra game data storage
3. cheapness of manufacturer

A 1x drive will be sufficient but let's try for 2x.
Top loader design. Off-the-shelf components if possible to allow repair shops to replace worn out CD drives without causing too much headache or cost to the owner.

Major Japanese developers are courted.
Long-form console gaming is the future.
With luck some good action RPGs are released for the Atari CD that catch on and steal the thunder of Zelda. Overall, the focus is on console gaming as a genre to itself, rather than bringing the arcade home.

refutations
>CD would be too expensive
Not quite. It's borderline but I've looked into it and by 1986 or early 87 it was feasible using the same tech used in portable CD players of the time.
>where does the funding come from?
Investors who are willing to take a chance betting on the company that made the VCS.
At this point in history the 5200's flop could be considered a fluke.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9606149
>drop development of the ST
That would be a really dumb thing to do.

Your best bet would be creating a console using largely the same parts as the ST hardware by modifying the bitmap shifter in the ST into a tile controller, reducing the 512K main RAM into a 128KB cache, and replacing the floppy drive with a sony or panasonic CD drive. That would save a lot of money, and it'd be a more powerful system than the PC Engine or even the genesis in some ways. The PC-E has no DMA and is unable to do sophisticated visual effects or complex math operations, it's just a beefed out sega master system. Tramiel could order those CD ROM drives in a bulk and get the best prices, he was good at that, but be ready to make a few enemies in the process.

Here is my hindsight-based design:

Hardware choice is up to my designers.
BUT
The hardware and its capabilities must be fully documented in a professional and easy to understand manner.
Said hardware must be considered to be "easy" to work with and I'm not going to take just one or two people's opinions on this, there's going to be a lot of testing and prototyping including sending out dev kits to major third parties and getting their feedback, if this results in corporate espionage I don't care.
The hardware is focused on fast action games with smooth vertical and horizontal scrolling and lots of colors on screen.
The controller will have at least eight buttons including start+select, games are getting more complex and I can think of a lot of scenarios where one or two won't cut it.
The controller will have a great and responsive feel to it that allows for sharp gameplay.
Top loader cart slot.
Power supply board inside the system if possible, I don't like power bricks.
Multi-out for RF/RGB and phono plugs for composite.
System aesthetic is blues/greens/grays, no woodgrain or plain blacks, but it can't be perceived as a girl's toy either, I'll know it when I see it.
Power switch makes a satisfying click when pressed. This sparks joy in the player.
No add-ons of any kind. It's just a games machine.

>>9583547
NTA, but.
Point-and-click game with copious CGI, impressive production values, batshit insane plot, full voice acting, and it impressed Nintendo so much they hired a lot of the staff for their EAD team. It's Japan-only, for the moment being. Only times it got talked about before was when collector hoarders accidentally leaked a private mega folder with tons of games including this previously lost game.
Company did 3 games like these and folded shortly after. Supposedly uses a Macromedia type thing.

Some copyright troll trademarked a bunch of stuff including the logo for the game and took down most of the media about it online, and it looks more like erasing the game from existence than a prospective new release. Nearly nothing is left online.

The game is about a 5 year old American girl identifying as a bear (and portrayed as such) going to dangerous locations after hearing voices in her head. The game opens with her being refused a bus ride, that bus is bombed by terrorists and everyone is dead, the terrorists are gunned by an airplane and everyone is dead, and the girl inspects the bus and goes "It can't be helped". Then she has to avoid dying by starvation, getting hugged to death by a pedophile cop, getting killed in the crossfire of other terrorists in a public park where a schizophrenic woman thinks the heroine is daughter, and then an alien locale that defies description. I'm saddened the walkthrough was taken offline. I really want to see how this goes now that I learned more Japanese. The backstory intro roll itself (which is in English) alone is a riot.

>>9596951
>>9596953
Anon who posted that. It's still the original files, but they are preinstalled on an emulated Windows 98 Machine so the game is easy to play

The ISO file is in a folder titled 'Files' along with the Windows 98 drive, and is mounted to the machine so the game can run, but is also there to make it easier to use and explore compared to the format of the original files

To run the machine, run "Launch.bat" in the folder

>qemu-system-i386 -nodefaults -rtc base=localtime -display sdl -L pc-bios -m 256 -machine pc,hpet=off,usb=off,kernel-irqchip=off -device VGA -device lsi -device sb16 -drive file=Files/w98.qcw -cdrom Files/CB1_DISC.iso -boot c

Its just a one line command that launches the machine with the correct settings, but I obviously get not wanting to run some random batch script and exe, so you can also move the files to your own qemu install and it'll work fine

>>9600572
Not much, but there are two things you can try that may help.

First is to change '256' to '512' to increase the amount of memory the machine has, though I don't know if this will really help.

The other, if you are on Windows and have the Windows Hypervisor Platform enabled, is to change this
>-machine pc,hpet=off,usb=off,kernel-irqchip=off
to this
>-machine pc,accel=whpx,hpet=off,usb=off,kernel-irqchip=off
which will improve the general performance through virtualization

This can cause some issues related to shutting down the emulated machine though, but its nothing major

I'd like to report that it runs on Wine 7.0.1 pretty much out of the box.
32-bit Wine prefix, set Windows version to Windows 2000, and just prefix your Wine command with LC_ALL=ja_JP.UTF-8 so the Japanese characters will render correctly.
Pretty much everything works (movies, mouse input, saving and loading). This might be a more performant solution than running that Windows 98 QEMU virtual machine, plus it should work on all modern OSes (Linux, macOS, Windows).

PCem/86Box are going to be even slower than QEMU. They're full-on low-level emulators that focus on hardware accuracy. If you think QEMU was slow then those are going to be even worse.
>>9601682
>>9601691
>>9601707
You actually can run Wine on Windows by using WSL2. That way you're still using a VM, but it'll be a sensibly fast one (modern Windows hosting a modern Linux guest) rather than a bug-ridden one (modern Windows trying to run a Win 98 guest).
Just download the "Ubuntu" app from your Windows Store and then `sudo apt install wine` and hey presto you've got Wine.

For anons who are suffering from bad sound running the Windows 98 QEMU VM, it's probably due to QEMU's poorly emulated SoundBlaster sound card.
In comparison the AC97 codec is much more open and accurately emulated.
To try that, change "-device sb16" to "-device ac97".
Then you'll need to install the driver. One possibility to to search for the "SigmaTel C-Major Audio AC97 WDM driver".

>>9604896
Good or not depends on if you like point-and-clicks. As for interesting, yes. It's a pretty high level of Japanese weirdness with pretty good (for 1999 PC games) production values.

It's about a 5 year old girl from New Jersey named Cookie Blair who sees herself as a teddy bear, the intro gives the backstory that a century ago aliens arrived on an island in the South Pacific and made an agreement with the island's president where they could own a part of the land if they shared their technology with him. They eventually started an annual Olympics-like sports contest, which Cookie wants to enter.

The very first thing that happens in the game is Cookie loses her bus pass, the bus driver kicks her off the bus, and then as the bus drives away some people drive up in a jeep with a rocket launcher and blow up said bus... which causes a helicopter to arrive and blast away said people and then fly away. There is apparently an alternate version of that scene where the rocket people and helicopter blow each other up.

It's also possible to die in the crossfire of two gangs in the middle of the park, pick up a spirit radio that lets you hear (ghost?) sex, die from smoking, find Laura Croft's corpse in a tomb, win a dance-off, and break out of jail. I am sure there are dozens of other weird scenarios I haven't encountered.

It's pretty wacky.

Of course I mean inside qemu (more accurately inside Windows 98). WDM is the Windows 9x driver type, not NT (i.e. Win 10).
Once you've downloaded the AC97 driver you'll want to pass the files into the Win98 VM. To do so put the files inside an ISO file and then when launching QEMU, add a "-cdrom /path/to/file.iso" to the command.

Looks like there's three different releases
>Eggerland for Windows 95 [1996]
>Revival! Eggerland [2000]
>Revival! Eggerland (EA Best Selections) [2001]
From what I can gather, the 2000 release added Windows 98 compatibility and the 2001 release added ME compatibility. Possibly also different title screens compared to the original release. These all have different IDs assigned to them too, like how HCMW-4001 is for the 2000 Revival! Eggerland and finding out that HCMW-4002 is for 2001 release while HEG-01 is for the original 1996 release. At least going from what I could find online where I couldn't verify with photos of the games, but can be helpful when trying to find the right copy.

>>9606821
If you mean the audio cutting during cutscenes, I don't how to resolve that.

But if you mean the audio being distorted and stuttery, that can be fixed by disabling hardware acceleration on the sound output inside of Windows 98.

You can do this by going to the Control Panel, then 'Multimedia', and then selecting 'Advanced Properties' on the playback device. Then select 'Performance' at the top and use the slider to disable hardware acceleration.

This is caused using the ac97 instead of the sb16

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Repost from >>>/v/625694309

How you can help with a translation

Yes, we need someone fluent in Japanese, with the same skillset needed for translating audio dramas or anime (less than 40 minutes of audio).
The audio is extracted as individual files with filenames out of their context.
That translator would need to transcribe all of them to Japanese (to make later revisions easier) first.
Then give his/her own interpretation of the text in English second.

Audio files are already extracted, but not organized in a very friendly way.

>https://mega.nz/folder/IGcQ3CJa#P6VUlCjXAJxdoiZHgqBLMQ
Get this file
>Asset rips/Audio Dump WAV.zip
It has all ingame sfx, bgm and voice acting, except for the movies.
They're all short wav files named like this
>dirOpened output of nms-1683.wav

From what I noticed, they seem to be following this trend:
>nms
general voice acting (1683 files)
>sky, swm
minigame voice acting / sfx (43 files)
>cly, ffh, hdl
more minigame voice acting / sfx (74 files)
>acs
mostly sound effects and grunts and background music, but some are voice acting like acs-196 to acs-206 which cover saving/loading the game. better saved for last (216 files)

Same mega.nz folder has another file for the movies.
>Asset rips/Movies.zip
Only a handful have voice acting.
They can be hard subbed probably, but a transcription would be better even for stuff that's in voiced/written in Engrish because the audio quality is generally poor.

For the transcript to be useful it could be formatted this way:

>acs-200
>オープニングムービーを見る?
>Watch the opening movie?

as a text file, covering all of the game files.
If you don't want to type acs/nms every time you can just type the number and just clarify which section it is in the beginning of the file.

>acs-196 to acs-206
Those audio strings already have matching visual text in English even in the Japanese version.
So the acs files are low priority, but should be checked just in case.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9609140
>Dumping (and maybe recompiling) the game's scripting seems possible, but I'm not even sure if Director supports any kind of subtitles. Have to go dig through the old documentation.

>What we have now
All of the audio extracted from the cxt/cst files: Can be transcribed and given a text translation
All of the movies are in an easily editable format that can be hard subbed
All visual elements are already in English: Don't need a translation
Sprites and all of their individual animation frames are easily extracted in Macromedia editor from cxt/cst files

>How the project can move forward

>Dub route - easiest, but worst
The extracted audio can be replaced with English equivalents. Not that many voice actors. However, it would lose SOUL.
The videos can be redubbed or subtitled fairly easily like old documentary shows

>In-Engine Sub route - keeps compatibility with W95, but might be glitchy/not possible
New images are added through Macromedia editor for all possible voiced lines. English text on a transparent background.
The game logic in Macromedia Director needs to be deobfuscated (still not done yet), every single audio call will be changed to call those new textures, they'd appear for a fixed duration of time (length of the voiced line) and then disappear
Might be done via cxt/cst modding but unsure.

>Modern Enhancement Sub route - ideal, but hardest
The executable, a glorified Macromedia Director projector, is modded in IDA Pro to intercept any calls for audio playback and displays proper soft subtitles overlaid on top of the screen from an external srt file with proper timing data (might help with multi-line subtitles, and more importantly the subs are no longer held back by the engine limitations + multi language translations are possible) - of course an external text renderer might need to be coded but that's really easy
While you're at it, it could intercept mov playback and override them with AI upscaled versions of the movies

>>9607478
>It's not a fun experience once you get over the thrill of having 10K games you *could* play.
This. There's nothing wrong with emulating, but personally I'd rather spend more time playing the games themselves than fixing input settings, visual settings, flipping between different emulators because the one you tried first had some problems, etc. With a console I just have to put the game into the slot and turn it on and it works perfectly and there's no problems. Emulation SHOULD be more convenient than real hardware simply because you can run so many games on one machine, and yet it's not. I also think freedom of choice is a problem. For some reason when I have a menu with a bunch of games I end up playing only for a few minutes and then switching to a different game. I don't know why it is but I always do this. Meanwhile if I have an actual cartridge then I tend to leave it in and will play a single game for a few hours and will actually try to complete it.

>I'm not sure if it's worth putting each cart in a bag or if that plastic will interact with the other plastic? I'm going with loose sheets of bubble wrap to minimize scratches for now.
It depends on the type of plastic. The sleeves I use are very specific and I know for a fact that they won't cause problems. I wouldn't throw my stuff into any random plastic bag for storage. Short term is fine like if you need to carry it between two locations, but if the game is going to be sitting in that bag whenever it's not in the console then you need to consider whether or not it's safe to put it in there.
I'm unsure about bubble wrap for long term storage, especially in the summer. I would definitely check what the brand you're using is made of and do some research.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9609075
>Can I ask what sleeves you use?
They're called "Crystal Pack" and are made by a company called Heiko. They're not specifically for games but they come in a variety of sizes which is great because you can get a perfect fitting sleeve for most types of cassettes. Also these have an adhesive on one side which will keep the sleeve shut, but it's not airtight so you don't have to throw in anything to suck up the moisture. But just in case, I actually use a thumbtack to poke a few holes in the same side as the edge connector to ensure that more air gets in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9609241
>Is it really worse than an actual Virtual Boy?
What does worse mean in this context? There is no better or worse, just different. The Virtual Boy displays games in 3D similar to the 3DS, and the emulator can't replicate it properly. It's better than playing on a flat LCD screen, but it's not the same experience as playing on the real hardware. The controls on the Oculus are similar to the Virtual Boy controller, but these games are made for d-pads not analogue sticks (although that's a minor gripe). One nice feature about the emulator is that you can change the color palette to something that's more pleasing to look at if the red bothers you.

If you can't justify the price for a failed device with only 22 games then the VR emulator is a great way to experience these games. At the very least it's a much closer experience than what a PC will give you. Plus even if you did have the real hardware you would likely have to repair it (even if you bought an NIB unit) due to how the screens are attached, so unless you're good at repairing old consoles then I really can't recommend it.

But whether you choose real hardware, the VR emulator, or a PC emulator, there are a few really good games available for the Virtual Boy which I absolutely recommend checking out! Jack Bros, Wario Land, and Mario Clash are all great games and there's a few others too.

>It's slow
You have a "give me another row of blocks" button.
It's not as fast as Magical Drop but that's like saying a cheetah isn't as fast as a bullet.
>chaining is too casual
I like the ability to switch blocks mid-chain. It's a lot more active than waiting for your puyo to pop.
>RNG
I can see the issue in this for versus, but I think it's fine for single player.
Frankly if you have another person who regularly likes to play obscure Japanese puzzle games with you you're already winning life so I don't see room for complaint.

A lot of this comes down to taste; IMO Panel de Pon is the best puzzle game ever made but some people are looking for a different experience and there's nothing wrong with that.
Give it a break for a few months and try coming back to it when you're in a different mood, you might be surprised by how much of a difference that makes. I didn't use to like it as much as I do now, it grew on me over time.

>The Game Gear one is the finished, full version of Sonic The Hedgehog 8 bit
Nobody believes your shitty meme, GGfag.

>The sprites for Sonic, invincibility, and shields were all redrawn to be smaller, to account for the reduced screen size and thus look less impressive.
>Warning signs were added near spike pits and cliffs in Green Hill in the Game Gear version. Casualization.
>The Special Stages have different layouts in the Game Gear version. On the first "loop", the stages have a time limit of 2 minutes rather than 1. More casualization.
>Due to the smaller screen, the Green Hill boss flies much lower and can be reached from the ground, making it a complete joke. Again, casualization.
>In the Master System version of Jungle Zone Act 2, the screen continuously locks as Sonic travels upwards through the stage, with the bottom of the screen acting as a bottomless pit. This little challenge would naturally have been completely unfair on the Game Gear, so it was removed. The boss of this zone was also made more casual.
>The first two Acts of Labyrinth Zone have radically different layouts between versions. Most notably, the Chaos Emerald is much easier to get. In the Master System version, the Emerald is sitting in the middle of a spike pit; to get it, the player must collect an invincibility power-up a few screens below, run through a lengthy obstacle course to get to the spike pit, jump in, grab the Emerald, and jump out before the invincibility wears off. In the Game Gear version, it's just... sitting there, out in the open, very near the end signpost.
>The final boss no longer enters a second phase, and attacks with three floor-mounted flamethrowers rather than a moving electric wall. The homing device was also moved from above Robotnik to the middle of the ceiling. Why so casual?

Enjoy being wrong forever and preferring the inferiour version of 8-bit Sonic 1.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9605143
Guy who animated porn in Flash, mainly of various cartoons and of some anime during the 2000s and early 2010s. He was very famous on 4chan once upon a time, in part for memery he engaged in and for coming here and interacting with people, making anniversary animations for the site, etc, but in part because he was just REALLY fucking good at animating, even in the late 2000s. He was good at imitating the styles of the works he made porn of, too.

Today, in the 2020s, Flash is a fading memory, and the guy doesn't do all that much of the porn animations anymore, instead doing freelance work animating for various games and other projects (which is the smart thing to do). Zoomers had little to no idea who he was until he did an animation of some characters from Animal Crossing a year or two ago, set to an old Sandy Marton song, and it got memed to hell and back, because zoomers couldn't really handle it.

tl;dr if you're a horndog and you've been a 4chan user for well over a decade, you would probably know who the guy is.

>Nor have they heard of map editors.
I'll have to play IArch-Vile's Advocate on that point.

Setting aside that OP's point is LUDICROUSLY insipid and retarded, if his argument is that there were no resources in December 1993 to tell you about all the secrets (even if there was), then map editing software wouldn't be a counter argument, as iD never published any tools for Doom, and people had to develop that themselves.
There might have been some incredibly rudimentary map editing or map viewing software for Doom during December of 1993, but if there was, it probably wasn't widely available, and probably wasn't easy for the layman to use. Mind, the first custom level for Doom ever made was created with hex editing, which was a simple square room that didn't even work because it had no nodes built for it.

Also, if OP is a fucking retard (and his posts strongly suggest that he is), I doubt he could navigate something like the trial version of DeepSea, or DoomCAD, because those programs weren't particularly graceful or userfriendly even for normally intelligent people, you had to just get used to the way that software sucked.
Kids don't know how good they have it with modern editors.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9609314
1. John Romero is known for talking himself up/gladly stand by while someone else talks him up. I don't hate him, he's great, and he genuinely deserves a lot of that fame and praise, but he's got a big ego, it's how he is, and it's something to keep in mind with him.

2. He's almost certainly being facetious and joking about this, he has a sense of humor, I'm 99% sure that when the secret area thing in Map 15 was talked about back then, it was because someone else jokingly framed it as "Finding Doom 2's last secret!" and that he's playing along with that. Game journos may not have gotten that joke.

3. There's a couple few levels where something was accidentally left tagged as a secret during the editing process and never fixed, and which there are no ways to actually access and register as discovered without cheats or exploiting engine quirks.
As an example of how things like these can happen easily, E4M3 had a corridor which is tagged as a secret, then when Shawn Green changed that corridor into a set of stairs, he didn't remove the secret flag in advance, and as a result every single step in that length of stairs is tagged as its own secret, which is something he didn't address, giving the level a whopping secret count of 22, 19 of which are those stair steps. Beyond a shadow of a doubt, Romero just forgot to adjust the sectors in question while editing Map 15, lots of great level designer have made that slip up.

4. These kinds of errors have been known about since 1994, especially since you couldn't score 100% secrets in normal gameplay, and map editors existed at the time to let you take a look at the level. In speedrunning, secrets which aren't possible to tag without cheats or exploits are waived, usually just requiring you to discover/reach the place, because it was recognized very early on as a bug and technicality.

THIS is what the CD-i was really meant, and designed, for.

The CD-i is more comparable to a computer that lacks all the stuff people used to buy computers for (text editors, spreadsheets, programming, art and music editors, etc) back before CD drives.

The idea was that if you didn't have any interest in a modern computer outside of its CD drive, a CD-i player was a much cheaper alternative.

The internet becoming a thing really killed the appeal of a CD-i player to Joe Average though. Suddenly people wanted computers to surf the web rather than to look shit up on their Compton dictionary CD.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9607320
>What games in the Tales series are worth playing
You won't ever reach a consensus on this one.
Legendia is kind of a black sheep in the series, not the worst one, but it was made by a different team, so it's like a Phantasy Star III to the Tales series.

It's also worth mentioning that all the retro Tales titles were made by 2 different teams, namely team Phantasia (character design is done by Kousuke Fujishima) and team Destiny (character design is done by Mutsumi Inomata).
Each team developed somewhat of a different style through time. I usually tend to favor the team Phantasia titles (Phantasia, Synphonia, Abyss, Vesperia), although even between those titles there's one that I particularly don't like.

Trends change fast, and 2D game designers that couldn't adapt weren't in high demand in the 2000s, and SNK was basically dying by then.
Knowing how Japanese companies work I woulnd't be surprised if they got shuffled to some non-development job in the company, handling paperwork or shipping and the like. You know Godzilla's first suit actor ended his career working for the film studio's bowling alley?
Plus most of these games were largely good gameplay with loose, but appealing concepts. The creators often weren't really tethered to these games beyond a design and programming level. Iga didn't create castlevania, but steered it in a direction that had his influence on it so he's more associated with the franchise than the ones who actualy created it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9596872
>brightness is at about 50% now
That sounds like too much. I have my Trinitron at 3 ticks out of 24 or so, while keeping contrast around the middle of the scale. There is some really slight black crushing, but I get almost true blacks this way.
Remember that "brightness" is the black level setting, and "contrast" is the actual maximum brightness. This has been mislabeled for decades, confusing people to no end. Fortunately some manufacturers have started to change this naming convention to better reflect what those settings do, like LG with their last year OLED models.
Now, to do this adjustment properly you'll need to sit in a dark room and bring out a brightness test pattern of sorts, for example the color bars in the 240p Test Suite. Then you turn down the brightness all the way and make your way up until the bar nearest to black gets barely visible (is a bit brighter than black). Similarly for the contrast, you want to avoid near-white highlights getting blown out, so you should be able to differentiate the value that's nearest to white from pure white. Realistically, you'll probably have to settle on some sort of compromise between true blacks and a bit of black crush as no display is perfect. But hey, that ghosting should be gone at least.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9604227
240p is strictly speaking an implementation of 480i, with a caveat. 480p is nice at least in principle but it's a pretty narrow subset of displays that can do it and handle 240p input timings properly through the same input (Dreamcast and PS2 are the only consoles with both 240p and 480p games, and not a hell of a lot of the former discounting backwards compatibility, and Dreamcast has issues with games and/or resolution modes outright not supporting certain connectors itself, but still) I don't know a lot about the Dreamcast, but PS2 and Gamecube tend to lower color depth for 480p so it's not an absolute upgrade and probably depends on how your display handles each and your personal preference. On an LCD with bad deinterlacing 480p is going to shit on 480i obviously.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9605516
>I never hear about how "records and discs won't last forever" from music collectors, but people who collect games always parrot that shit.
I like to use car guys because they're the best example, but basically it's people who know about their hobby vs people who don't. For example most car guys know what's going on under their hood. If something happens to their dream car then they can usually pop the hood, investigate and figure out what the problem is, and repair it themselves. And if they don't know how then they'll reach out to people who do know how and ask for advice, learn how to fix it, and then get it done. But then when it comes to games, it seems that most gamers just play games and don't know anything about what's going on so when a problem arises they're shit out of luck. They don't know anything about the hardware so they just repeat whatever they heard in YouTube videos, which are made by people who also don't know about the hardware. All it takes is one Metal Jesus to say something stupid and everyone who watches them and also doesn't understand the hardware will repeat it forever because they trust the channel they watch much like boomers trust their favorite entertainment news channel.

In the coming years, more and more consoles will become in need of basic maintenance, and as that happens more and more casuals will probably turn to emulation because they're too scared to learn how to change a battery or a capacitor. My hope is that as a result of this, more and more retro gamers who play on physical hardware will become more like car guys and actually know what's going on under the hood. You don't have to be an expert, but you should be capable of basic repairs and upkeep and currently most people aren't. However, my fear is that during this transition period a lot of perfectly serviceable consoles (and maybe even games) will get trashed by retards because they're "broken."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Did its devs know how incredible Ocarina of Time would be while working on it?
posts.com:
Just watch the intro:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s7mkGC_1yF0
Of all the things they could show you to get you pumped up when you start the game, it's your character galloping a horse on the planes with bits of almost ambiental music. If you don't press any button, the BPM decelerates even further and you're watching what looks like two grannies executing a ginger belly dancer. All of it feels like something that you don't even know how to feel about, besides being profoundly atmospheric and lightning in a bottle. Even other more subtle intros, for example Crystal Chronicle's, feel very much bombastic in comparison and almost "tryhard".

Similar to the simple Zelda cover arts, it feels like it was done by people who didn't just have boundless confidence in their product but were also very aware of the cultural impact it would have in the future. I wish there were interviews where they talked about random stuff like this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9611525
The official story is that only two bullets struck people in the motorcade. One bullet was the headshot on JFK (that one hit no one else). Before that, one bullet entered JFK's upper back, exited near his throat, and continued on to wound Connally who was sitting in front of him. Critics say that a single bullet could not have caused all of the non-fatal wounds to JFK and Connally and would have had to take a "magic" flight path to do so, changing directions more than once. The official story is that the critics are misrepresenting JFK and Connally's seating positions, and that yes a single bullet could cause all the wounds while traveling in a fairly straight line, or at least a path that's reasonable for a bullet to take after penetrating flesh and bone.

>>9605047
Ah, you're right.

https://tcrf.net/The_Legend_of_Zelda:_Ocarina_of_Time/Version_Differences

I know that 1.1 fixed a ton of bugs, but I also thought it was censored from 1.0. Looks like they didn't get around to censoring the game until NTSC 1.2 or the first PAL release.

Also...
>Japanese/USA 1.0, 1.1, 1.2 N64 releases are alternatively known as NTSC 1.0, NTSC 1.1, and NTSC 1.2 respectively. Although they are technically different binaries, the only difference between the two is the country code byte in the ROM header, which is used to set the ROM's default language. There is no in-game language selection feature.

Wait, so the entire game is in both Japanese and English on all NTSC versions? But instead of having a language select... they hard-code which language the game will use? That, yeah, that sounds like a perfectly Nintendo thing to do. I would have assumed this was a cheap attempt at trying to region lock/discourage imports, but they already had a (pathetically easy to overcome) region lock on the N64 AND the game released with only a two-day difference between Japan and the US (Not like YouTube or Twitch was a thing back then and importing would have taken longer than two days) so there was zero point if that was the reason.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9605195
That sounds like a pretty shitty deal even for 2012, yeah. Retro overpricing was heavily ramping up by then.

I sold just the BOXES for some of my old consoles and N64 games for several hundred altogether. In fact, I sold some of the extra consoles I had lying around that I no longer need and they went for much less than the empty boxes, unless it's a more recent console.

I was never much of a collector, at most I like to collect some of the more noteworthy games or ones from the past that I just really liked but I never cared too much about the boxes or condition over just playing the games. I have no desire to have a "full collection" for a console like some have, at least, not in physical form. I lucked out a bit though, went on a spending spree for old N64 and PS1 games around 2006, a little before the retro-boom. I remember it being considered expensive to pay more than $10 for a PS1 or N64 game that wasn't something rare, Amazon was full of hundreds of sealed boxed copies of Perfect Dark for $3 each. Managed to snag dozens of the N64 and PS1 games I always wanted to play, or had rented and loved but never owned for $1-5 each. Even ones that are expensive nowadays like Conker, the Banjo games, 007, every WWF game, Yoshi's Story, Mystical Ninja, Bomberman, and a few others... sadly I think I didn't get Diddy Kong Racing or the Turok games. Most are just the cart, but a few like Conker are CIB... that have actually degraded a bit because I had no idea I should have stored them well at the time.

That being said a few are special to me, such as a copy of Megaman 1 complete in box that I got for a mere 25 cents at a garage sale less than a year ago. I was very very tempted to sell it since that tends to go for over $300, but I wanted to just have at least one thing special since as far as I am aware nothing in my entire game collection since I started gaming in the NES era is special or rare and decided to keep it.

(Also, WATA can go burn in hell)

posts.com: What's the best way to play OoT today?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9610589
Mupen64Plus-Next using the ParaLLEl plugins in RetroArch with 4x resolution downsampled back down to native with a CRT shader. If you don't like RetroArch or CRT shaders, you can alternatively try it out on simple64 or RMG, again using the ParaLLEl plugins, and if you want hi-res, use those same plugins at 4x resolution. Be sure to play using the version 1.0 ROM, though, since it has no censorship and it has some fun glitches that were patched out in later versions. Additionally, you can try the Redux fanmod that adds some QoL stuff like being able to equip and unequip Iron Boots on the fly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
James Pond is one of those European Amiga games that got console releases too.
Whenever people talk about it, it's always the second game Robocod, and I think usually the Genesis / Mega Drive version, and it's been re-released of a shitload of systems in some fashion, even Switch.

Nobody really talks about the original game that was a James Bond MGM parody, or about the third game which is set in outer space. James Pond 3 is pretty solid and gets ledicrously fast, much faster than Sonic does on his home system.
There was also an Olympics spin-off game that's often forgotten.

Also, all the covers for James Pond games always depict him holding a gun, parodying the James Bond movie posters, but I don't think he actually uses one in the games?

>it could be possible to reproduce the CMOS variant used in the Genesis 2 although not the NMOS VDP in the Model 1
Why's that? I don't know anything about chip production.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9599906
70s-80s chips were often NMOS logic. This is when all the transistors in the chip are n-doped. It has the disadvantage of using a lot of power and getting hot as it forces every transistor in the chip to draw current even when idling, and it also produces a lot of signal line noise and can have glitchy behavior due to how the logic works.

All modern chips (anything designed in the last 30+ years) are CMOS logic, which is a mix of p and n-doped transistors. It is much more efficient and cooler running as idling transistors do not use any power and it's free of signal line noise and glitches. However it was not widely used for years as it was more complex to manufacture and early CMOS chips were very slow (solved when they found they could just thin the metallization layer). CMOS chips are less forgiving of sloppy system design as they can be damaged by a bus conflict as that will drive the signal lines on the chip high, while NMOS signal lines would go low.

IIRC Mega Drive chips were all off the shelf so some beautiful autist is definitely whittling away at this. Exciting times in this sector of retro development, OP! Get psyched. :)

PPUs up to Revision E were still sinked but it was a flat piece of aluminum instead of the spreader under the chip which seems to have only appeared on the initial faulty production run. that Famicom in the link seemed to have a non-working CPU however there was a Japanese guy who had a functioning revision 0 unit and found it had several differences including (apparently) not being able to do the full 8 sprites per scanline. the PPU ran balls-hot and it had a lot of RF interference in the video signal (solved by later installing metal shielding around the cartridge slot. Revision 0 Famicom boards are very rare as they were recalled and most replaced with a Revision B board for free.
