>>9600147
There's a capacitor on the GND and CHR/RD pins of the cartridge slot. That seems to have fixed the issue with Rambo; apparently some problem with corrupted CHR data. A resistor pack links the VRAM with one of the TTLs (?) and there's resistors/caps attached to the power rails in three different places. They're tied to ground on the other end. Maybe these were put there to improve power line filtering.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9596485
The grades exist to nudge you into playing the game in a way that will be more fun and skillful. It's basically an informal difficulty selection, if you're okay with getting a sub-par rank on every level the game will be easier but less satisfying, just like as if you had played on easy.

Anyway, there are benefits to being considerate about how you attack but I'll grant you don't NEED to do it to beat the game, but even so you need to do things besides button mashing to avoid damage, unless you just tank it all with items but again that's playing on babby mode and an impractical playstyle that's essentially equivalent to skipping the gameplay.

That said, I do kinda get the sense this genre pushes you much harder to learn how to properly defend than it does how to attack. Learning how to deal a lot of damage, combo, or improve your style rank/score is all a lot more optional than learning how to not get hit, and I think it can contribute to these games feeling more button-mashy on a casual level. Something that also bothers me about them is that for all the hype around sick combos, a lot of the enemies can't be meaningfully combo'd. Humanoid bosses in particular can often be stunned, allowing you to wail on them for a bit, but no matter what you do to them during these sections they just sit there: you can't move or manipulate them in any way, all you can do is deal damage. It's lame - I'm not saying you should be able to infinitely combo them, but if they're going to have a "vulnerable" state you can trigger, make them comboable when in that state.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9596384
Devil May Cry is considered a hack and slash game, which typically involves fast-paced, combo-based combat. The game does rely on button mashing to a certain extent, but it also requires players to master a variety of different techniques and mechanics in order to be successful. This includes mastering different weapons and abilities, juggling enemies in the air, and dodging enemy attacks.

Some players might find the game to be button-mashing, but many fans consider Devil May Cry to be a more skill-based game that requires players to master the mechanics and develop their own playstyle to truly excel.

It's also worth noting that opinions on games are subjective, some people may find the game to be too simplistic while others may think that it's deep and challenging. What is important is that you enjoy playing the game and you find it fun.

>>9605023
It's based on three criteria.

Time spent on the level:
Orbs obtained, hence why you need stylish to finish off enemies - they drop far more orbs if you keep combos going;
Damage received, you need to learn how enemies and bosses are designed and what patterns they use so you can safely attack them without being hit.

Also, using any items will immediately put you in a critical threshold on any of these, you're basically forced to get a perfect ranking on all of them if you want to use 1 item per level. Mission 22 is batshit insane to S rank because you can't rely on them.

>>9607325
>Ammo system means beam switching is much deeper than “switch to red for red pirate”
I wouldn’t say *much* deeper. The ammo system only really matters during boss fights, where missing your shots actually has consequence because running low on ammo actually puts you at disadvantage. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I played them on the Wii Metroid Prime Trilogy collection. The major difference, besides the controls, is apparently Prime 2 has some difficulty adjustments for some bosses so the game ends up being a bit easier.

Out of Prime 1 and 2, I think 2 barely edges it out for me. I think Prime 2 really hones down the aesthetic of the Prime games into something unique, where Prime 1 has some generic aesthetic choices. This is also apparently controversial, but I actually really like the beam ammo mechanics. There's a bit of a survival horror edge to Prime 2 because of that: besides the zombies in the opening, the Ing, and the whole dark world.
I think Metroid is at its best when it's a little scary, and Prime 2 might lean hardest into the spooky aesthetics I like from the series, besides what you get in Super.

In terms of environments I'm a massive fan of Torvus Bog: it reminds me of growing up in Florida, but has this lovely feeling in certain parts of it like you're not supposed to be there. Like exploring some dark corner of a sewer system that hasn't seen an intelligent soul in decades. Torvus Bog following after Agon wastes is also a bit genius: you go from this oppressive desert for the first third of the game to this area drenched in rain. I think that has an impact on why I like Torvus so much. Quenching, thematically.
Prime 1 has Phendrana drifts which almost singlehandedly puts Prime 1 on par with Prime 2 for me. It's just that strong. But again I think there's a lot of little improvements in 2 that eek it out over 1.

The only thing I don't like about both games is the ending "collect 9 temple keys" fetch quest.
Which is something I want to say for 3: I think Prime 3 is sadly a little underrated by people. 3 mostly fixes the "9 keys" fetch quest by doling out the energy cells through the main mission, so you only have a handful to collect at the end. 3 in generally handles its final sequences much better. It's much more climactic than 1 and 2.

Great games

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Regarding backtracking in the Prime games, I was never impressed with it in any of them.
Super Metroid is great: the movement mechanics in that game are more satisfying so it's actually fun to do stuff like bomb jumping, wall jumping, space jumping to areas you couldn't reach before, etc.
Movement is good for what it is in the Prime series, but I wouldn't say it's a highlight. The backtracking is more reliant on your ability to solve new puzzles with new equipment, that acts like keys to locks you couldn't yet open.
I might actually be a fan of 3 the most, if we're talking about backtracking, where you have these 3 main areas that are each sort of like Zelda dungeons for you to tease open as the game progresses, and they lean into the strengths of the Prime games with some of the most interesting/least frustrating puzzles.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9609818
Not really, just roll with PAL60, use this list:
>>9610038
...sometimes it's down, but Google has a cached copy.

Beyond that, there's a few games that have more content in PAL releases (Everybody's Golf as an example has the biggest character roster), your best bet is to go through the titles that interest you one by one using TCRF's website and checking the regional differences tab.

Some games back in the PSX era were optimized for PAL (anything by Naughty Dog) or ran better on it (Hogs of War), but for PS2 that's not nearly as much of a case.

So yeah, PAL60 is your best bet and if a given game doesn't support it, check the differences between the PAL and NTSC releases.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
my favorite part of Final Fantasy VII is a part of the game I never hear talked about: Icicle Lodge and the surrounding world area.

Everyone talks about Aerith's death but nobody talks about where the game puts you afterwards. The melancholy of the slow piano melody combined with the desolation of the area, only to be followed up with a strangely comforting town in the middle of nowhere with friendly residents and cozy wintery lights. The people here never knew Aerith, and ultimately your suffering doesn't affect their life. Life goes on after loss, and it can make you feel empty and alone.

It's a beautiful moment of atmosphere that only few games are able to achieve.

Just wanted to share that. Sit down and listen to this and reflect with me, /vr/. https://youtu.be/Quxjw0jfJ3Q

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Battletoads.

Battletoads is not hard in the same way Ninja Gaiden, Zelda, or Castlevania are hard. No matter what you say about those games, their mechanics can be mastered. Even if it's really damned unlikely, it is still POSSIBLE to make it through even the most difficult sections on your first try, if your skills with the mechanics are honed. Battletoads is not like that. It is literally won through trial and error. Throughout the entire game, there is not one fucking action taken that a reasonable person would expect any player to make on a whim. Beating the game requires you to die multiple times. Period.

>>9608513
Yep, when I got a Game Boy Pocket on a family trip to Tenerife, I also got a multicart for it. It claimed to be 32 games in 1, but it was more like, 12 or even 8, and the games were just listed again with different titles. Apparently some multicarts actually feature modifiers or cheats for the game when you select the alternate titles, but as far as I could tell, this wasn't the case with mine or my brother's, and it was the exact same game.

I can't seem to find any pictures online of the one I had, and I still have that thing lying around somewhere, so I guess I should dig it out and take a picture of it just for reference's sake. I don't think these things have much value, but there's some niche collectors who collect these bootleg Game Boy carts because they're fun and usually very cheap, some of the more unusual ones don't even have a menu interface, instead they have pic related, a little button on the cartridge body which you press, rebooting the Game Boy and loading the next game in line.

Due to extensive research done by the University of Pittsburgh, Battletoads has been confirmed as the hardest NES game known to man. The research is as follows. Pocket-protected scientists built a wall of iron and crashed a Battletoads cart into it at 400 miles per hour, and the cart was unharmed. They then built a wall out of Battletoads and crashed a car made of iron moving at 400 miles an hour into the wall, and the wall came out fine. They then crashed a diamond Battletoads made of 400 miles per hour into a wall, and there were no survivors. They crashed 400 miles per hour into a diamond traveling at Battletoads. Western New York was powerless for hours. They rammed a wall of Battletoads into a 400 mile per hour made of diamond, and the resulting explosion shifted the earth's orbit 400 million miles away from the sun, saving the earth from a meteor the size of a small Washington suburb that was hurtling towards mid-western Prussia at 400 billion miles per hour. They shot a Battletoads made of iron at a car moving at 400 walls per hour, and as a result caused two wayward airplanes to lose track of their bearings, and make a fatal crash with two buildings in downtown New York. They spun 400 miles at Battletoads into iron per wall. The results were inconclusive. Finally, they placed 400 Battletoads per hour in front of a car made of wall traveling at miles per iron, and the result proved without a doubt that Battletoads were the hardest NES game of all time, if not just the hardest NES game known the man.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Sorry if this gets a bit away from OP's topic, but I was sent on a nostalgia spiral on the subject of those Game Boy multicarts. Let's see, going through my memory, I think me and my brother had these games on ours, some shared, some not:
>Tetris
>Dr. Mario
>Battle City (port of Famicom-only game)
>Snake (Serpent, ergo Snake but with some added gameplay depth compared to the classic ones, has very awkward controls though)
>Flipull
>Tom & Jerry (based on that not very good movie, I liked the cartoons way more)
>Super Mario Land
>"Super Mario 4" (actually a reskinned Crayon Shin-Shan game)
>Hercules (based on the Disney movie/cartoon, was kind of awkward and difficult to play, didn't enjoy it much)
>Alleyway (a good Breakout clone)
>Othello
>Bomb Jack
>Hugo (one of those Crazy Castle games, with that European cartoon troll I never quite liked)
>Motocross Maniacs
It ranged mostly from decent to very good, so combined with the number of titles, the value was through the roof, thank God for piracy! Tetris even worked with the link cable.

>>9609792
I saw mention of an Atari 2600 multi-game cartridge which actually WAS 128 in 1, but it was one of those button cartridges, ergo if you wanted to play the 128th game on the cartridge, it means you had to press that button to reboot and cycle through each game in order to get to the end, 127 times.
I'm glad that multicarts with a menu interface are more common, I'm not sure I would have played mine as much if I had to do that manual cycling shit.

>>9609904
I saw some recollections others mention where this stuff was really inconsistent. Like a cartridge could do that thing where it has a bunch of repeats, and MOST of them are the same as the last time, but then one or two is modified like that to start you on a later level, without any of the other ones doing stuff like that.

That's only half the issue. The other half is you are constantly being blindsided by hazards you could not possibly have anticipated without trial and error. I'm not exaggerating here. Absolutely NOBODY is going to get through Volkmire's Inferno without dying AT LEAST 3 times, their first run. Nobody is going to know how to dodge those bubble-blowing things in the final stage before they instantly kill you. Nobody is going to know which direction those wheels you have to outrun in Terra Tubes will turn at the end. Nobody is going to anticipate the multiple times in Arctic Caverns where the game decides to drop you into a pit of spikes.

If ANYONE considers this good game design, or "subversive", or "innovative", they're probably a legitimate sociopath.

>level names were conceived to be food puns ala Kirby's Adventure

>Ridicule Root was renamed to Dangerous Depths after the food theming was removed

I motion for Ridicule Root because it seems the level was probably known by that name longer and the abbreviation is less confused with Desert Dazzle. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9592276
>>9592278
You don't need a FX2 chip. All the FX2 did was support larger ROMs than the FX1, the FX1 otherwise performs the same as the FX2. Many people assumed the FX1 runs slower from trying to use Star Fox 1 as the doner cart, but the chip used in Star Fox 1 was slower variant called the Mario Chip. The ROM of Star Fox 2 is small enough to be fully addressable with the FX1. The most likely reason that Star Fox 2 was going to use a FX2 chip is that they were probably not producing the FX1 anymore, not that it needed it. Even if the FX2 cost more to make, having production of both FX1 and FX2 going on at the same time when any FX1 game would run the same on a FX2 would have cost more.

There are far less games that had a FX2 in them, and even less that had battery SRAM. About your only option outside of Tealand is Doom and Yoshi's Island, both rare and expensive.

Meanwhile the Dirt Trax FX and Stunt Race FX games can be had for $10-15 at times and there were tons of those. Yeah, it does suck to have to cannabalize older SNES games to make one of these, but there is no real way to create your own from scratch due to it being an FX game. No homebrew way to create your own FX chip. I mean, it can probably be implemented with a FPGA but I have zero clue how powerful (and thus expensive) an FPGA one would need. I tried to lookup the hardware in the FXPak but all I could find was that a prototype from 2011 used a Spartan 3 FPGA, no idea if the current carts also use that. Depending on the version they go from $18 to $120, most seem to be $18-40.

As for making it, many have made such a repro in the past. Most of them back then were made with the beta ROM that was floating around for years before the SNES Classic. Issue is with this having been done years ago, most guides are listing parts that are no longer easy to get (mostly the EEPROM) but if you know what you are doing you can use just about any viable EEPROM that's big enough and has the necessary pins.

It has to do with the speed of the combat and how mobile the character is.

In something like Bayo or Ninja Gaiden you're so much more faster and agile that it wouldn't feel well. Zelda games and Maximo are much slower in combat and you move a lot less. There are sometimes inputs that use the 360 but between 2 different attack buttons, fast enough frame data to make use of pauses (eg A,A vs A,wait,A), and the many ways you can dial up an attack there is no reason to resort to these inputs which as I said are going to feel bad with how fast and agile these newer characters are.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
N64 was the "tech demo" phase for a lot of this stuff. Really showing up all of the different ways a character can control in a 3D space, and all of the different things you can do with an analogue stick in gameplay.

After that, we move into the stream-lining phase, where developers are thinking less about what the player "could" do, and thinking more about what most players are going to want, which is simplicity of controls and mechanics. That's either a good or a bad thing, depending on how you view it.

Seems like it was very common for an N64 game to have different movement speeds, climbing, swimming, crawling, ledge grappling, first person view modes, and flight all baked into the design, while a modern game like Elden Ring might not necessarily have even half of those options.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9594662
more options doesn't necessarily mean better. OoT was a very good start on 3D combat but right now I would say there are two game series that influence 3D action games the most: Devil May Cry and Dark Souls not retro though.

The prior focuses on giving the player as many combat options as possible and makes that the fun of the game. Launchers, flying attacks, guns, ways to combo enemies, parries, everything you could want to do. These games are more about being stylish than just outright winning the fight. However this limits the enemy design as these games can quickly become unfun if there's too many enemies you can't combo effectively, or if the bosses act in a way that's too limiting to your arsenal.

While the latter is the exact opposite, you have an extremely narrow set of options in combat. Block, dodge, light swing, heavy swing, shoot projectile and maybe a few more options. While this seems limiting it allows the developers to focus much more heavily on challenging enemy design based on how enemies respond and require you to use the few options in your arsenal. People generally love boss fights in these kind of games for this exact reason, every single boss is like learning a song in a rhythm game since its mostly been simplified to "when do I dodge and when do I hit?".

OoT has a lot of options that lack purpose. Yes you can angle your swipes, horizontally or vertically, but what value does that have over just hitting the B button? The answer is none because enemies don't respond to things in ways that warrant you to change that. Would crouch stabbing have any value if it wasn't just objectively the best DPS in the game? I don't think so, because no enemies have a mechanic where you need to crouch to evade their attacks. Dodge mechanics are hardly even necessary because only a tiny few enemies can threaten your shield, I can't even think of any other than Darknuts.

So I think that answers your question, quality > quantity.

Recently I saw a video by one of those innumerable British game essayists on YT reviewing Rayman 1 and going through every level in the game in excruciating detail, making dramatic commentary about how "hard" and unfair this game is, particularly singling out the "trigger" mechanic in the game that spawns enemies and obstacles if you pass by a certain point.

I have been hearing a lot of people say that this game was very difficult, but I remember playing this game on PC as a child and I didn't have any trouble with it at all. I mean sure it is rather challenging at points especially Cave of Skops, but to say it's "the Dark Souls of platformers" is really silly. Apparently this sentiment has been prevalent ever since it released? This is the first time I'm really noticing it. A lot of people online are saying this game was ball-bustingly hard or they never beat it. Are people just really bad at platformers these days? I don't get it. It feels more like a zoomer thing to say because I relished in the challenge. I didn't cry about having to hunt for lives or have only 3 hit points. I just found out you could have up to fucking ten (10!!!) hitpoints in the DSiWare version which I just find completely kekworthy. The trigger mechanic never bothered me either because I just learned to brace myself whenever I heard the sound cue, which is a VERY distinct sound you can hear easily ahead of time.

That leads me to my next question: Which is the definitive version of the game? Is there anything that the PS1 or Saturn versions have over the PC version? And how do you feel about Rayman Redemption?

The game is trial and error but it's manageable. It only becomes hard because of the lives system, nothing in the game actually requires good execution (outside of 1 or 2 parts like the infinite hover hair sections) but there are many parts of the game where you will need luck not to die in your first attempt.

People nowadays and get frustrated when they run out of lives because they feel like they've wasted a bunch of time. Rayman has a punishing lives system because you can gain lives by collecting 100 tings but you lose those when you die, meaning you can be in a situation where you've died 2 or 3 times but are effectively 5 lives down from where you would be if you had played perfectly. The flipside of this is that it makes getting the early levels memorised very satisfying as you can reach Picture City with a huge amount of lives saved up.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9606612
Here's my overview of the series as it stands in 2023

SMT5 is the most approachable one just because of how many QoL features are shoved into it (like compendium fusion) and the fact that you can avoid battles whenever you want
SMT3 is the one I started with, it can be really unforgiving at times but it's phenomenal. The HD remaster is fine (it's lazy) but it adds a major QoL feature during fusion that doesn't make the game easier but saves a bunch of time
SMT4 is known mostly just for being the easiest mainline entry and having a totally retarded true ending path, but its still good. SMT4A is worth playing if you liked SMT4 just because the core gameplay is even better, even if everything else is retarded
SMT Strange Journey is excellent as well but imo it's not the best place to start. It's more in line with "classic" SMT. But it's really great.

SMT1 is probably not the best place to start imo, but the new PS1 translation is the way to go for this one
SMT2 is definitely not the best place to start imo, probably the worst of all mainline...

SMT If... is considered the proto-Persona, it is extremely polished for a Super Famicom RPG. There's also a PSX version with an easier difficulty but i dont think this is translated...
The Persona games are also worth a look, I would probably start with Persona 4 (P4G is fine too if that's easier to access now). Persona 5 Royal is easily the most braindead easy game in the entire megaten franchise so that's the easy recommendation for someone who is totally unfamiliar with JRPGS and the series at large. Despite it being piss easy it has a lot to offer in terms of presentation style stuff.

Finally there are dozens of spinoffs, but the one I would recommend first and foremost is Devil Survivor.

Sorry for rambling but I would say if you are experienced with JRPGs I would go SMT3 > SMT If... > SMT5 > Persona4 but there are genuinely no wrong answers aside from starting with SMT2

Have fun!

>>9605746
This is from Super Mario 2 J for the FDS.
If you touch the flag pole when the last digit of the timer and the two digits of your coin count are all the same you'll get a 1up. You don't have to touch the top, you can be standing right next to it at the bottom.

So you'd need 44 coins and touch it when the last digit is a 4. Or 22 coins and 2, etc.

This makes it very easy to get a lot of 1ups in this game.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9605746
I have a weird one. I could swear that I played Warriors of Rome III for the Sega Genesis on Sega Channel back in the day. They put unreleased games on the service now and then and that was one of them. Warriors of Rome III was confirmed in development at some point but was never released. There are a small handful of blurry screenshots from old magazines. The ROM has since never been dumped, and no one else who had Sega Channel seems to remember it ever being on there aside from ONE post I found on some obscure forum, but that person doubted their own memory, too! To this day I don't know for sure if I played it or if I might have misremembered the playing the second one, but I could swear that I did. I remember it being listed in a section with all three Warriors of Rome games and picking the last one because it was the latest. I played it for days on end and looked for it by name when emulators became a thing, but the only evidence it ever existed were the one or two "upcoming games" listings in game magazines.

>>9574470
Mine was also a 32GB Memory Card. When started to having this problems I just formatted everything and tried to start all over but didn't work. So I swapped for the 4GB Memory Card I had and everything started working fine. Installed Enso on him and passed all the files from a fresh install to the SD2Vita that I bought and made a backup for this files because if anything goes wrong I have a safety. I also removed the Memory Card and didn't install anything so now I have two backups.
In your case you don't need to do all that >>9574464 if you already Enso your Vita using your Memory Card, you can just copy all the files from your Memory Card to the microSD(after you formatted correctly) and swap the ux0: on the YAMT settings and point to the SD2Vita. After that I recommend you to stop using and remove your Memory Card and just leave him as a backup if you didn't make a backup after you hacked your Vita.
Reminder to only do this if you Enso your Vita.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9574813
They designed games around using both screens. Nintendo pushed pretty hard for devs to make use out of the touch screen feature for the lower screen, and this led to quite a lot of square pegs jammed into round holes out of obligation, ergo needless and obnoxious gimmicks foisted on the player. Dawn Of Sorrow comes to mind, the stylus adds exceptionally little to the gameplay, and it actually flows a lot better if you use a romhack which removes the mandatory stylus poking.

Eventually this would be more relaxed, and thus for a lot of games, the second screen didn't serve much more of a purpose other than being something like a map screen, inventory screen, or status screen, which you could manipulate with your stylus if you for whatever reason wanted to take your hands off of the controls.
Those could be pretty convenient and handy in some games, but they also wouldn't have suffered if they only had one screen to work with. Some games were made with the touch screen in mind, such as some drawing games, or Trauma Center, where its application is actually pretty cool and thematically well placed, but most videogames aren't the kind where using a stylus on a screen is a critical or badly needed feature.

So, a gimmick which kind of could be cool for the right kind of games, but which was widely unnecessary. I want to liken it to if the Virtualboy could have been hooked up to a TV to play the games in regular 2D, and then only early games were made with the 3D in mind while most devs just put token efforts in for the 3D and expected you to play it on your TV.

To make this post more retro, the original DS had a slot for GBA slots, of course, so beyond the thing playing DS games, you could play all your favorite GBA games, or pick up later ones for cheaper as the market was moving away from it. Also, some DS games could have some form of interaction with prior GBA titles if two relevant ones were inserted, typically bonuses in a DS sequel to a GBA game.

Yeah it sucks, but here's how I cope on a modern diamond controller setup:
>left face button as A
>bottom face button as B
>right face button as C
>L1 as X
>top face button as Y
>R1 as Z
>L2 and R2 as the shoulder buttons

>>9592401
There's no physical back button by default, so you basically have 3 options:
>swipe up from the bottom of the touchscreen and tap the "Back" triangle on the bar that appears, or do equivalent "Back" gesture if you selected that option under system settings
>hold whatever button combo you set to activate mouse mode (for me it's L2+R2) down for 3 seconds, then press the B button. In mouse mode, the B button is mapped to "Back", and X is mapped to that thing that lets you view all open apps.
>try this https://retrogamecorps.com/2022/01/16/retroid-pocket-2-starter-guide/#Home
I have yet to find an emulator that doesn't let me map the "pull up menu" function or w/e to R3, so I just do that.

not the same anon but I have one. Its actually one of my favourite handhelds. Definitely go for the trimui version, they are slightly nicer quality. Its not immensely powerful, & i thought it was going to be too small to be comfortable, but custom firmware did quite a lot for performance (& completely eliminated screen tearing). It was surprisingly comfy to hold, i usually get cramps on small devices but this seems to be fine for longer play sessions. The buttons & dpad are some of the best ive found in a small form factor handheld. Clicky & responsive, great for fighting games.

I also own an anbernic RG280m & RG350mp which i got around the same time as the trimui model S. I use the model S much more than i use all the others combined.

I never see people talk about these on here which is sad since its a super comfy handheld.

Every enemy in perfect dark “acts the same”.
In Halo they literally don’t. Each enemy variant has a role and truly work as a team to kill the player you.
Every enemy is reactive. If a grunt feels overpowered they will run away. A team of grunts will take you head on and swarm you from all angles. Jackals engage in hit and run tactics. Hunters to have the most simple AI, but they are designed to be mini-boss bullet sponges/stresser.
I’m replying to bait and I know I am but just in case some retard goes and repeats what you said I’m setting the record straight.
Goldeneye has better AI than Half-Life, that’s something actually true you can say to upset people.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9605914
Hate to tell you, brother, but it's a lot simpler than that. A controller doesn't work particularly well for managing a large arsenal. Limiting the player was a necessary sacrifice to make an FPS play well on console before they figured out alternatives like the modern weapon wheel + slowmo. The slow movement is also artifact of trying to make an FPS game play well with limited controls. In the end, it gave Halo a unique identity and the gameplay does flow well considering, but don't deceive yourself into thinking that "was the point".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9600430
1 is a straight up isometric metal gear
your offensive choices only stun enemies, core gameplay is about stealthing around enemies over several dungeons, its old school linear (stage 1, stage 2, and so on) no rpg mechanics

Boktai 2 introduces stats(STR,ENG,AGI), level ups, a variety of offensive options, you can now defeat enemies or still stealth(backstabbing triples damage) and a decent sized connected world map with a hub in the middle, progression is linear like modern zelda games (must beat dungeon A before you can visit dungeon B) but you have a certain degree of freedom to roam, grind and craft itens

Boktai 3 ditches the connected world map
and goes back to stage selecting, bigger dungeons but outside dungeons you only interact with npcs through menus

>Also can I enjoy 2 without having played 1?
Yes, you get a recap at the start of the game

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9607189
Only had problems with these, they're not worth it and many popular PS2 games don't recognize it. Memcardpro's solution will be the best thing, in the meantime here's a few options:

As >>9607225 said, in ulaunchelf you can copy over saves to a usb drive to clear up a memory card, a good solution because it also keeps compatibility high.

In OPL you can generate virtual memory cards (VMC) which work in many games but not all of them.

Pic related, the Katana brand memory card, 16 and 32MB versions exist (2 MC/4 MC) which with the press of a button switch to different 8MB banks to save your games. These are a little rare and the 32MB ones are pretty expensive but this is a reliable, officially licensed solution.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9600930
To be fair, DX Sonic has a much higher polygon count than the DC version, but I agree that people overblow how "weak" the DC was. People forget that the DC can run most of its library in 480p, while the PS2 can mostly just manage to hit 480i (which is really just 240p but doubled). In truth, all the killer apps for all of the consoles of the time were highly specialized to the hardware they were built for, hence why most DC ports look dramatically worse on PS2, or sound better than on the GC. The DC definitely couldnt run the post-processing effects of SH2, but I don't think the texture work would be impossible as the DC has texture decompression, while the PS2 doesn't. I really think we never saw what the DC was completely capable of as a lot of techniques were developed later in the gen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I couldn't find a 1CC thread in the catalog, so here it is. 1CC stands for one credit clear, usually being used to describe arcades, so completing a video game without using a single continue, though its meaning can vary depending on what you're playing, for example when regarding consoles, the concept of credits isn't really identical to how it is in arcades, so many consider a console 1CC to be a completion without losing a single life, instead of simply not using continues, though opinions may differ, and some still consider a console 1CC to also be a matter of simply not using continues at all instead.

>What 1CC are you currently working on?
>What's the latest 1CC you've managed to get?
>Which 1CC of yours are you most proud of getting?
>How do you perceive console 1CCs to differ from arcade?

I struggle a little with 1CCs, as I do love the idea, that of mastering whatever you're playing completely, which is what it takes to even stand a chance, but it can definitely be a shame to be on a good run only for it to go to waste near the end. I personally consider a console 1CC to be a perfect run, not losing a single life, unless we're talking about arcades, which is where this idea originated from, and with that in mind my proudest 1CC is probably Sonic the Hedgehog, the original SEGA Mega Drive classic, I grew up with it, so getting a 1CC, and with 100% completion too, was both fun and special to me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9607195
Can't help you much without a replay of yours, but:
Use C-Shot, probably the best for a clear (better than C-L because of the power down after death). But if you're more comfortable with the A type go with that. B is kinda tricky but perfectly usable.
Don't be afraid to move up, as you deal more damage if you're close to an enemy. It's the only way to deal with the 2 last stages without bombing too much. With C-S, being near the top of the screen and spamming your regular shot (not the laser) will destroy so much stuff before they even fire (works great against the "needle" enemies in Stage 3 for example).
Learn how to get the extend in the 3rd stage if you don't know already.
Just bomb a lot, you get more than 30 bombs for a loop, you should be able to skip a lot of hard stuff this way.
There's a trick to "skip" the second half of the 4th boss which you can see in some replays, but I find it hard to setup (and even good players mess it up sometimes), honestly for a scrub 1cc just bomb during the second half if you get cornered, and focus on learning the rest of the game. It's only useful if playing for score.
And the usual "learn where dangerous enemies spawn so you can kill them before they even fire", as it's extremely important in CAVE games. You don't have to bother with that for the first 3 stages, but you'll need it for the second half.

>>9607543
GaiaSeed on the PS1 is a really cool game whose only flaw is that it's too easy. Give it some love.
Harmful Park (also on the PS1) has more challenge and depth of strategy, but is still easy *once* you've found the correct strategy.
Darius Gaiden with autofire is easy enough while still counting as an "adult's" shmup. Enjoy the trippy space fish aesthetic.

But keep in mind that people (very good players even) play some shmups for years and years while never getting the 1CC, and blindly focusing on those may not be a sound way to enjoy these games.
